During the 1st century BCE, the island was ravaged by anarchy and starvation, and the very survival of Buddhism was threatened. This was because at the time, its teachings were orally transmitted by monks, and many had died or left the island. We visited Ambewela Farm during our honeymoon and honestly wish we had never come. What should have been a pleasant, scenic stop turned into a disturbing and upsetting experience that cast a shadow over what is meant to be a once-in-a-lifetime trip. The reality of this place bears no resemblance whatsoever to the advertising. Promotional images and online listings show cows grazing on lush green fields in open countryside, suggesting a humane, natural farm environment. In reality, the animals we saw were kept almost entirely in concrete buildings with concrete floors, with no access to grass, natural habitat, or direct sunlight. The conditions were visibly dirty and bleak. The rabbits were the most distressing - confined to tiny, overcrowded cages, with multiple rabbits forced into each small enclosure, unable to move freely or behave naturally. The goats were kept in cramped box-like pens, often with three or four goats squeezed into a space barely large enough for one, including mothers and young separated into very small additional pens while the young feed and grow. Nothing about this felt educational, ethical, or aligned with modern animal welfare standards. Instead, it felt like animals were being displayed purely for tourism, with comfort and welfare coming far from second. To experience this on our honeymoon was genuinely upsetting, and we left feeling saddened rather than enriched. Based on what we personally witnessed, the marketing imagery is misleading, and visitors who care about animals should be aware that what is shown online does not reflect the conditions on site. To top it off, we found it extremely hypocritical and ironic that during our visit we encountered a sign which read ‘obstructions and cruelty to animals is a punishable offence’. If this statement were true, this entire facility would have been shut down a long time ago. I would strongly not recommend this place to anyone expecting a humane, open, or natural farm environment. really good place to visit but when the weather is not good the whole trip gets spoild. it is good for the children too. Ruins at Buddangala Monastery in Ampara District - The few monks remaining in this monastery braved intimidation by Tamil terrorists and starvation to keep this timeless heritage floating. Princess Chitra established this 1000-acre monastery in 400 BC, after she left Anuradapura. The Buddhangala Monastery lies deep in the jungles about 7 kilometers off Ampara. The Monastery covers 1280 acres covering 5 rocks where the remains of the ancient monastery can be seen. This area belonged to the Digamadulla Kingdom which was started by Prince Dighayu in the 4th century BC. All though the beginning of this monastery is not documented, Ven Ellawala Medhananda Thero states that the history of is monastery is as old as the Digamadulla Kingdom. Lost in the history, covered by thick jungle infested with wild animals, exposed to the elements for over thousands of years, this monastery was brought back to life in 1964 by a young brave bikku called Kalutara Dhammananda, (incumbent high priest today) who traveled through the thick jungles and cleared the area with the assistance of Buddhists in the area. Hidden among a thick jungle full of wild elephants and leopards is the Buddangalamonastery, a Buddhist meditation Centre, which is nearly 2300 years old. Established in the second century BC by a provincial Princess named, Chitra;the ruins of a once thriving temple and monastery is found scattered over an area of 200 acres within the jungle. The standing ruins spreading across five rocky mountains scattered with ponds tells the story of a vast hermitage in the days gone by when Ampara was a flourishing agricultural and trade base in the East of Sri Lanka, then known as Digamadulla. The Brahim letter inscriptions on the rock face explains the procedures of building the temple under the guidance of Princess Chitra and the supervision of her accountant , a written evidence of affluence and opulence of the age old Digamadulla. The monastery had been built in and around a rocky mountain scattered with caves and ponds, which are now the home and play grounds of many a wild beasts. The temple which is found on site today is built on a mountain which holds the finely carved stone remains of five buildings and a ruined stupa, which is yet to be excavated. The half standing stone bridges and stairways suggests that the five rock scattered mountains found amidst the jungle were interconnected creating a 200 acre large monastery comprising caves constructed with the distinct drip ledge and remodeled with cement, bricks and plaster. The monastery which maintained a continuous Sanga tradition until the years of 800 AC were later abandoned due to the shifting of Kingdoms and South Indian Invasions. It was forgotten amidst the rising jungle and left for the elephants to roam for more than thousand years; until the monastery was rediscovered and reestablished for the meditating monks in 1964. The new stupa of the hermitage, which stands on a 500 feet tall hill top, is enshrined with the relics of Lord Buddha and his two main disciples;ArhantSariputta and ArhantMoggallana. The relics were found on site during the excavation of a stupa and are a unique and ultra-reverend combination for many a Buddhists in the country. Although the end of the civil war, which engulfed the East coast of the country for the last two decades, had seen an increase of travelers to Ampara, Buddangala monastery still remains hidden among the jungle, aforest hermitage of ancient tradition. We booked 2nd Class reserved seats from Colombo Fort Station to Kandi by making a phone call to the Fort Railway Station. We were quoted the correct price, given a receipt number and informed that we could pick the tickets up on arrival at the railway station. We travelled by taxi from our accommodation in Negombo, heavily laden with backpacks and additional day packs, and arrived leaving an hour before the scheduled 8.30 departure time on Good Friday March 30, 2018. After locating the appropriate ticket counter (Counter 17), we were told that there were no tickets booked for us, the receipt number was incorrect and there were no available seats on that train or any train to Kandy on that or subsequent days. As there was a line of other customers behind us, we left the counter and went to the Railway Tourist Information Office next door. The office was not yet open but a helpful person told us that we could put our bags down inside and wait for someone to help us. We accepted the offer, respite from a crowded footpath and a seat in an air conditioned office. After making his morning offerings, a man named Sampath told us that he would inquire about the availability of tickets for us. He came back some time later with the information that there were no vacancies on the 8.30 train as it was a very busy holiday, but he would see if he could get us tickets on a later train. He made one or more phone calls and told us that it would be possible to get tickets for reserved seats on the 10.30 train. After much coming and going we he returned and revealed that the seats were available only as part of a package holiday involving accommodation and drivers/guides. As we had already booked accommodation in Kandy, he "helpfully" put together an itinerary based on our travel plans. We were a little surprised at the quoted costs but, as new arrivals in the country and feeling trapped in Colombo on one of the busiest travel days of the year, were in a good position to be exploited. We agreed to a much shortened and cheaper version of the 15 day package that was offered. The full package cost the equivalent of (Australian) $1 700 for 15 days. This exceeded our budget and did not match our desire to plan our travel as we discovered more about the country and what we wanted to do in it. The final deal was for 2 one way tickets to Kandy, 4 nights of accommodation in Sigiriya, and a driver/guide to drive us from Kandy to Sigiriya, to our destinations for the next 4 days and back to Kandy on the last day. While we waited for the process to play out and our tickets to be obtained we observed the same scam being used on a succession of European and Asian travellers by the other officials in the Information Office. The accommodation in Sigiriya was good but the driver, while seemingly friendly, offered very limited advice or details and at every opportunity tried to persuade us to go to costly tourist attractions and buy safari and village tours, which we declined. We have since discovered that the accommodation was owned by the "tourist information officer" and he has been using this as his main source of bookings for a long time. This scam is well known to many within the tourism sector in Sri Lanka and is not limited to Colombo Fort Station. The cost of both the accommodation and driver were inflated, so that the 76 000 rupee ($A 654) we paid was well in excess of what we would have paid by independently booking. Stick to information from the official government tourist offices which are located at the airport and in a number of cities throughout Sri Lanka. They do not receive commissions or kick backs, offer good advice to travellers, are very well informed and put together itineraries that match your interests and allow you to see everything possible in the budget and timelines available to you. They also book you excellent  drivers that (while not seemingly cheap) have great knowledge that they enthusiastically impart. One modern aspect is the display screen but one could not trust whether the information was accurate. It was very noisy, sometimes painful to the ear as each train entered and left the platform. One could hardly hear the other speaking. Maybe I am old and sensitive to this noise. There were security/ticket checkers sitting at entry and exit points. However it was easy to push through the crowds and enter the station without any checking. Inside the station, there were some seats but not enough for the number of passengers waiting. Our train was to Jaffna leaving at 5.45 am. I wanted to check something about my ticket. There were no information or ticket counters inside. However there was a room where several men were seated behind their desks. There were no computers, everything done manually. If you expect western standards you may think the men were not interested and unhelpful. However, this is the way it seems things are in Srilanks, there are no queues and people tend to push with the 'me first' attitude. I did get my answers to my questions but also advice that one of the trains I had booked my return journey was a slow train taking 10 hours. I was grateful for this information and was able to change my ticket. Unlike airports there are porters to help with your luggage I did not see any porters here. I actually loved this antique railway station. I had a trip from Colombo to Kandy. It was pre booked. Train arrived on time and had a wonderful & safe journey. Gate ticket checker was polite and willing to give directions . But inside the station was not properly maintained, managed. Toilets were disappointing. Food stalls were really busy and they didn’t care about their customers. I bought 02 no’s of vegetable roti from one of stalls which was close to platform 02. I was so disappointed to say one vegetable roti was spoiled.Both had different fillings as well.I brought that matter to stall owner, it seemed he didn’t care. All they need money and they have an enough flow of customers.May be that might be the reason.Please stop selling spoiled foods. Kind enough to give value for money. At least not to argue. Used plastic bottles, plastic bags were scattered everywhere. It seems nobody cares. An ambience of the station must upgrade, facilities should also update as station is not only visited by locals but also  by foreigners as well. Food stalls should be audited for food safety plus security. For your reference. Thank you for everyone who helped. This station serves the entire Sri Lanka very well. But if yo are a Traveler who are going to use this, be ready. This is not a very clean and tidy place. This station is very crowded. Specially 6.30 a.m. to 6.30 p.m. How ever there are facilities to book long distance trains. So allays book your train. Most of the times trains goes as scheduled. Important advice - get here with plentyof time to spare!  There are people everywhere, trains coming and going, bewildered tourists wandering around, locals cramming ontop carriages and no signs or announcements which platifrm your train departs from.  You need to find someone official looking in a uniform and ask which platform your train leaves from and then probably get a second opinion!  As I said, a great travel experience. There are several trains bound to countryside. So you can find your way through train which is very cheap compared to other form of transpotation.There is  counter to reserve ticket in advanced too. This is the main train station in srilanka. but it is horrible place to see. very unclean and no facilities for foreigners also for locals. staff are very lazy and they don't inform very well. very disappointed place to have a tickets to go badulla. We were expecting the worst based on the mixed reviews on TA but to our surprise it was ok. The station was clean, very busy and hot with very few amenities. Signs are not cleared but there are enquiries counters which will aptly guide you. For our case, we were directed to counter no 17 (berth/intercity/reservation/Expo Rail) which essentially is a small air conditioning room. Inside this room, just queue at the respective ticket counter. We showed our pre booked Expo Rail reservation no on mobile (no print out required) and our boarding ticket issued. In fact you can pickup the pre booked Expo Rail boarding ticket before your scheduled departure from 6am-4pm daily (note: counter 17 close lunch time 12.30pm-1pm). Aside on Expo Rail was excellent. Clean, comfortable A/C ride, with free wifi, clean toilet, snacks, bottled water and movie. Heading towards Kandy on Coach 3, best seat 2, 4, 10 on the right with big window. Others have 2 smaller windows. Seat 5 has no window. 3 star for the station, 5 star for Expo Rail. This is an old-style railway station with nine platforms. There are separate toilets (accessible by key) for foreigners.  The male 'general' public toilets weren't spotless, but they were far from the worst I've seen in Asia. The station can be very busy as hordes of commuters use it. Long distance trips such as to Badulla or (shorter) Kandy are extremely scenic.  Fares are cheap, and some trains have openable windows that are preferable to air conditioned carriages. There are some shops, and provided one takes the usual precautions with smartphones and wallets/purses/bags, the station area is safe. Staff are helpful though the level of English proficiency varies. One of the main down turns is the very discourteous staff from Ticket collectors to the booking office. They have forgotten that it is the "PASSENGER" whose fare pays them their salary. To them the passenger is a botheration. They glorify in the 8.30 to 4.30 job they do, like the man just mechanically issuing tickets, the person who announces train arrivals or departures merely stating a train is cancelled not bothering to inform what time the next train would be. It is a rudderless leaderless place  with a station master who prefers to remain invisible. All the trains starts to costal line, up country , North trains starts from colombo fort. There is booking facility also. They announce all trains in English too. So it is convienient to travellers. There is canteen and washroom facilities too, if you are a foreign there is one special washroom facility in platform no 1.  In evening and morning this station is very busy. Colombo Fort Railway Station is the main Railway head in Colombo. The station building is a colonial era building, which appears to have stuck in the 1980s. For this reason, it has an old world charm to it. It is a relatively small station, however, since Sri Lanka does not have a vast or elaborate rail network, the stations serves the purpose quite well. It is a busy station and appeared crowded. Station itself is maintained neat and clean. The railway staff at the station is quite helpful towards the tourist. For the foreign traveller arriving first time at Fort Railway station, looking for luxury travel may have to rethink again! Fort is hot and chaotic and once you enter the railway station, one cannot escape the experience outside to the similar experience inside.  There is a sense of urgency about everything and yet without the rush. Trains depart to a different timetable to the listed departure time adding a memorable experience to your travels, but not if you are in a hurry to get to work! The good news is that in the midst of all the hustle & bustle, the system works. The best part of the train journey is chugging along the scenic coastal route. I urge any traveller who is brave enough to take a train ride from Fort to various island destinations to experience the train ride as well as enjoy the sites along the coastal route. If you are brave enough, you can also taste various local food carried up and down the carriages by local food traders.  Taking a train journey from Colombo Fort, should be a mandatory experience by all travellers! To travel by train is a turistic attraction in Sri Lanka. Than why not to start here. You can buy cheap and expensive tickets here - there are turist agencies for special trains here. The building of the railway station is nothing extra, but this is the main train station to everywhere - than a goog starting point to travel. The trains are always late and there are no information boards to know which train is which. But there are some local people to help you (they understand the only srilankan announcements) to know which is your train - naturally for money, then give them a tip. The hub in Colombo for trains and the place can be very crowded with people travelling to many destinations in the country. Advanced reservations are required for special seating's. The local train is a smart way to travel within Colombo, especially when one is not pressed for time. The Colombo Fort station is located next to the Pettah market and is walking distance from the Port area as well. busy & main station in sri lanka. full of people but that is ok. luggage room is quite small but staff is kind enough. cheap price for luggage store. good Drop off in front of the station, 10 platforms, and several matrix signs with departure information. Multiple small vendors, benches to sit on the platforms, and free of charge toilets spotted at platform 1 (I didn't check them out, do no idea of the state). If you want to see Sri Lanka then you must take three train rides one to Kandy the ancient capital the other to Newra Eliya and the other trip to Galle all along the coast be prepared for a trip of over 21/2 hours ,the trip to Kandy will take just as long as they stop at every station and its an event in itself with all the hawkers offering you all sorts of short eats , you can get first class seats or do the backpacker thing and go with the natives the train is always full so you can end up standing all the way the scenery is breathtaking and the trip to Nera Eliya 69000 feet up is a  must its just one of those things you need to add to the 100 list befor you depart this beautiful earth the only living planet in our solar system. do not worry you will return to dust from which you came and  be resting till the resurrection . I have been to the for railway station many times. The service we get from teh staff at thr railway station is good but needs to improve. I would be much happier if they could smile and be a little bit more friendlier to us. Heritage at its best. We took a train to Kandy and amazing is mere a word. Old world charm by well managed. If you have already planned your stay you should be fine, it is an average rail station. However if you are a tourist who looks remotely lost you will be escorted to a local travel agency where they will meticulously help you plan your trip and then inflate the price a ridiculous amount. Please don't make the same mistake we made. We went to the station to inform ourselve of the schedule and price for the train to Hikkaduwa.  Sadly we couldn't take it from a station stop near our hotel, we had to leave from the main station. It's a very big station but pretty well organize, it's easy to get information and buy tickets to go where your want. The train seems all to be on time too. That day we took the local train back to our hotel, it was only a short ride but it's was fun, the track along the ocean makes it a nice scenery and it's pretty cheap, it's worth trying it Easy to find and people are very helpful. But inside bit dirty. Although few displays are not showing the information number of display boards are there to find train time tables went to the place very bussy area  lot of people waiting to travel directions are not clear to buy tickets at the station they change to counters  very often Don’t even bother. We got dropped off by the tuk tuk at the back of the station and directed around the front to the ticket counters. In our daze and confusion we were beckoned into the tourist information centre and relaxed thinking we were about to receive some help and direction. However, what we got was some guy making what I have come to believe is a bogus phone call to check on train tickets for us to Anuradapura. He then proceeded to offer us a package deal including driver and accommodation for £70 a day!!! He showed receipts from other travellers before us and everything. We were hesitant so were encouraged to check trip advisor because he has nothing but excellent reviews. Jokes on him, scam scam scam. We declined and we are so glad we did. We got seated tickets on our desired train and, despite him telling us the Kandy-Ella train was fully booked, we got standing tickets on the day. Avoid the tourist information guy, the train station itself is fine. Exactly what you would expect from a busy Sri Lankan city. went to see th e busiest place in colombo the indian and SBI are there. and people are pouring in all roads. the traffic is well controlled and so it is easy for hr pedestrais to cross the road. We walked to the station, asked where to buy a train ticket and got pointed in the right direction. Five minutes later I had our 2nd class tix to Kandy for a few bucks. Easy as pie and the train arrived and departed on time. It is a long bumpy ride but you will have some great scenery to enjoy as well as people to meet on the train. Its the main Railway station of Colombo from where you can get Sub Urban and Long Distance Trains... Located in the heart of Colombo...Old Colonial Building...

Destination Title: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden
Document Text: Damro Labookellie Tea Centre and Tea Garden. Found this was more enjoyable than I thought. The factory tour was really interesting to see the processes. Our guide was so lovely and very informative. We’re from England so love tea and this was the best we ever tasted! We know now all the stuff at home is blended but the single origin premium quality they produce is so good. Definitely recommend this place and the tea they sell there is reasonably priced so we bought some to bring home Good place to visit testing tea.any one want a really experience about tea,visit that place and buying for best tea in the Sri Lanka. Interesting place and you are in Sri Lanka so you have to go to a tea plantation. A working plantation and 24 hour factory with a visitors centre set up for tourists. The whole thing is well done but of course the gift shop is more expensive than in the town. You can also do a 4 wheel drive tour which we did not do but according to people staying at our accommodation it was well worth it. Very stunning tea factory just outside the main city area. The factory tour was great, and having a tea and cake looking out to the tea fields was really lovely. Went on Last Saturday (13/08/2019) to have a cup of tea from Damro Labookellie Tea Centre. Was waited more than 1 hour after placing the order. But didn't receive it. Also the staff was very impolite and not speak properly with customers. This need to be corrected if you need to run this in future in good quality. Stoped off at this tea plantation en route from Kandy to Nuwara Eliya. Very busy with lots of tours. I got a lovely lady who gave me the factory tour . I really enjoyed it and learning about the whole process from planting to harvesting and processing. This was followed by a complimentary cup of tea and a slice of delicious tea cake ( small fee). You then had the option of purchasing some teas from the show rooms. Best Tea Factory by far, the fee tour and tea tasting was amazing. Set in a perfect location! Definitely order the cake with your tea at the end!!! Amazing!! A good tour of the factory telling you all about the process, it was interesting... Smelt amazing. Tour guide was knowledgeable and friendly. Lovely cup of tea after. Good shop with full range of teas as you'd expect. We have a guided tour about the work steps of tea - from picking to cupping in German it was very interesting to see what is done here Finally we got three cups of tea for tasting for free The very good cake was to pay The adjacent shop invited you to shop but you could not have. I want to thank this person for his great sympathy and kindness in showing us the LABOOKELLIE factory. I don't remember her name. The price of the tour to the factory is too expensive is 30 euros per person, it is interesting the explanation they give you, they give a free Te rate which you must accompany with something of the letter q they present you, the road to know the tea plantations is very deteriorated, you go all the time taking leaps, I hope that the wages they pay their workers of the plantations are decorous because it is a very hard work that women do in the sun , I did not see anywhere q could rest, drink water or eat something or q I saw no signs that they had anywhere to rest or go to the bathroom at any time. I get a very bad impression of the conditions of the workers on the plantation. The "leadership" has max. It took 10 minutes. It's free, but you don't really see anything. Especially no employees.  It's reasonable to assume it's an abandoned factory. Afterwards there is a cup of tea to sample but then you are urged to buy (overpriced). For a lot of money (60€) you can pick tea yourself and get photographed. The experience is not really worthwhile. Maybe there are better alternatives? We enjoyed our factory tour and tea tasting very much. Our guide was delightful, and the surrounding scenery was gorgeous. There is a large shop where you can purchase tea in various containers but no pressure to buy. Tour is free although we tipped our guide generously. Disappointing Experience – Not Welcoming to Asian Women As an Asian woman, I felt deeply uncomfortable and disrespected during my visit to this tea factory. From the moment we arrived, the staff consistently directed their attention only to my boyfriend, who is Western, and completely ignored me. At reception, the woman arranging the tea tour asked only about my boyfriend’s nationality and spoke solely to him, despite both of us standing there. During the factory tour, another staff member again asked only about his background—and not mine—while asking other couples (including a Nepali couple) where they were from. Later, in the tea room, the waiter brought the menu and asked only my boyfriend if he wanted to order anything. When he declined, the menu was taken away without even acknowledging me. It felt as though I was invisible. This kind of behavior from a well-known tea brand is incredibly disappointing. No one should feel disregarded or devalued based on their ethnicity or the nationality of their partner. I sincerely hope the management reflects on this and improves their staff training to ensure a more respectful and inclusive experience for all visitors. This is a tourist trap for sure, the very quick tour of the tea making plant was informative and the guide was helpful;. I think the tour should have shown you some actual tea picking  and a walk in the tea bush fields which very close by. The after tour free tea was nice but hurried. Lots of variety on sale, expensive but like most we bought a packet as a souvenir . Lastly yhre Health and Safety in the factory wasn't good, no belt guard and a big wheel at knee level spinning vey fast, accidents waiting to happen. This was a free tour, you could pay a tip at the end if you wanted to but there was no pressure.  We were asked to sit and wait 5 minutes for an english guide who was very good and she explained the process to us very clearly and we saw quite a lot.  I was impressed with the tour and felt it was quite comprehensive. 150 year old factory and the wood the use in drying process.  You get a tea tasting at the end and can buy teas if you want to, but again there was no pressure to.  Got to purchase a slice of cake to go with your tea which was really nice.  We had already watched the tea ladies picking the tea, so this was ample for us and enjoyed very much.  We could also take photos which other tours dont allow. I love tea and this place was everything I hoped. Our guide that took round the factory was friendly and very knowledgeable. We were not rushed and could take lots of photos and ask as many questions as we wanted. Wish we had picked tea leaves ourselves but the weather wasn't great . The tea room and cakes were gorgeous. I didn't feel pressured into buying anything. Didn't take too long either and the cafe and decked area offer fab views. Being tea lover, thought of buying some best tea from a very big tea estate and as promoted by them, I bought both Golden tips and Silver Tips tea. There is no aroma in it and though looks good but taste is not there. So without flavour and aroma, I don't see anything special in their best of the best teas. For people visiting first time in tea estate, will be good experience but suggest not to buy expensive teas from here Really enjoyed the tour and tea at Damro. Our guide was very helpful in explaining the many steps involved in making tea. After the tour, we were treated with some quality tea and delicious cake. The estate itself is very scenic and has some walking trails. The tour of the production process was very interesting (albeit it only takes about 10-15 minutes) and our guide was very knowledgeable and spoke good English. You don't pay for the tour or a cup of tea afterwards (a piece of cake you do pay for) but the tea to purchase in the gift shop was very expensive compared to what you could pay for similar in a Sri Lankan supermarket My favourite part was the tour and how they really explained it Tips for future Travellers get the tea cake and the chocolate cake it is amazing the tea is absolutely awesome 🤩 Lovely place to visit, especially if you are a tea afficinato! Many varieties of tea on display and for your putchase.  Frankly I found the tea prices quite high and overpriced....not sure why Silver and Golden tips were about $40 USD for a small box!!! Staff on site to answer questions and help you select our purchase. There is also an indoor and outdoor tea garden.  You are served 1 cup of black tea each person for free and can additionally ourchase a slice of chocolate cake to go along with your tea.  It was an ideal and pleasant experience. Very interesting tea factory tour, we got to pick tea in the plantation. Check for leeches after! We had a piece of fabulous light tea butter cake and got to taste their super fresh BOP tea. After I was able to buy a lot of tea from their efficient tea shop. The place was absolutely crowded so the staff rushed people to try and get through the number of people that were there. They joined two tour groups together and then rushed through the tour. The tour guide had excellent English and she ended it by seating us at a table and asking if we wanted a cup of tea and piece of cake (the cake would cost extra) and pointing out the shop. When we went to the shop and asked to taste the tea, we were pointed to the tea tasting area. Apparently this should all have been explained during the tour. However, she was too busy trying to rush through the tour to bother. With so any tea plantations in the area, choose a smaller one which will give more personalised service. I would say that was the most coolest tea I have ever had even without sugar.Exactly this may be the reason why they say sri lankan tea is the best !!! Nice surrounding & friendly crew too ! We came here on recommendation. There are always free tours on offer, which are entertaining and free, but don't take long. The process of making white and black tea is explained. At the end there is a free sample (breakfast tea). If you want cake: 450LKR (very tasty!!) Extra sample of other types: 250LKR each. In the shop you are not pressured to buy anything. And we really liked it. We visited on a Saturday morning and the drive from Nuwara Eliya to Damro is not far but the views was absolutely breathtaking as it was a clear morning and seeing the people working in the plantations was an amazing sight. At the tea factory we were taken on a tour by a very knowledgeable guide and we truly enjoyed it and learned a lot. We then had a very nice cup of tea to finish off the tour. They do offer tours (safari) into the tea plantations but we did not do that. Would recommend a visit. We did find the shop a bit expensive. No customer service. Please give some training about how to handle customers. If local customer service area is full it’s better you transfer them to foreign area without asking us to leave. It’s such a shame you guys are treating foreigner more than locals. The service should be equal. Staff only give 100% to foreigners not locals. Very disappointed about damro. Located near Nuwara eliya, damro is a national tea brand that makes a lot of variations of tea. This one is located amongst the tea estates and offers a great view of the valley. The staff takes you for a guided tour of the tea estate which hardly runs for 10 minutes and then offer you a complimentary cup of tea. The focus here is on selling lose tea and tea bags which are highly priced. Overall a good place if you have never visited tea estate of plantation. They also have a  cafe where you can have some good stuff though priced heavily. Fantastic. Excellent place with a view of the plantations. Indelible memories. It is possible to visit the factory and taste the tea... Never knew there were soo many varieties of tea. Was nice to see inside a working tea factory. The complimentary tea at the end was nice too. Shop is a little pricey though. The lounge/show room is located at the Labookellie tea estate factory premises about 20 km from Nuwerelia hill resort town. The emphasis on the name of the tea brand seems to have changed  from being Damroo to Labookellie. The original brand name was Mackwood Labookellie Tea Estate which is about a century old tea brand. The place is crowded with foreigners and the parking lot was too hot with  no tree for shade. The overstretched staff were busy with their hands full. It took considerable time to draw the attention of the staff. The smile from the sales staff is missing. Free pastry and tea were provided for the visitors. The packaging of the tea has improved with airtight containers. The price of the packaged teas have also been considerably jacked up. The company seems to be going in the reverse direction by increasing the  tea prices many fold  while the janatha is clamoring for reduction in prices. Instead of buying good quality but over priced tea packets from the show room, visitors could also explore the other tea show rooms in the vicinity like Rothschilds, Oakray Tea Bush, Ramboda for alternatives. The company could also explore reverting to the original name Mackwood Tea brand if IPR licenses are still held by the present owners. Expensive. Nice place.  We were take tour of the tea manufacturing life cycle.  Followed by tea.  Amazing place.  We purchased ginger tea which was really good compared to what I had earlier. We stopped here on our way from Kandy to Nanu Oya. The views of the tea fields are amazing. We had a short free tour around the factory which was really interesting and informative. Then they offer a complimentary cup of tea which was delicious. Bought a couple of items in their shop, more photos then on our way! Perfect place to stop for half an hour on a journey through the mountains Tour was not long but very informative. Beautiful views from the car park. Bought a lot of tea but beware the White tea is very expensive. I asked the price of several boxes and they were no more than 790 rupees. When I got to the till I discovered the Gold white tea was 8500 rupees. Bought it anyway but just so people know there is a big difference in the price of some of the tea. Now back home and it all tastes amazing- drinking the ginger tea just now and it is beautiful. Well worth the money. We had a very informative tour - unfortunately it was on a Monday morning, so there was not much going on in the Factory as the pickers did not work on the Sunday. The guides are all provided by the factory, so are very knowledgable The tea lounge serves an excellent cup of tea (as you would expect) and the cake is scrummy and very reasonably priced. Well worth a visit This is a tea plantation with great views onto the hills at Nuwara Eliya. On arrival, you'll be offered a pot of tea for free, and you can buy a slice of rather nice cake to accompany it. After that, you'll be shown around the factory floors where you can see the process of grading, drying and conditioning the tea leaves. It's a short tour, perhaps 20 minutes, but very interesting. After the tour, you can browse in the shop if you wish to buy any of the products. Very good. We had a lovely guide called Shiroma, she was lovely and had great English. We enjoyed the tea and cake afterwards Explore the iconic Damro Labookellie Tea Factory with Cultural Ceylon Tours. Nestled in the lush hills of Nuwara Eliya, this historic factory offers a unique insight into Sri Lanka's world-renowned tea production. Witness the intricate process from leaf to cup and enjoy a refreshing cup of Ceylon tea amidst breathtaking views. We visited Damro as it was recommended by our driver and it was a great tour, incredibly informative! We were driven into the plantation, where there are some wonderful viewpoints and picture opportunities and then got to pick tea ourselves, with our guide also explaining which leaves were used for what tea. Afterwards a lovely employee showed us around the factory, whilst quite a brief tour it was informative and interesting and she was very nice! We were served some tea to try for free and I also had the tea cake (400 lkr = 1.10$) which was very nice! We had a tour first. Then we some tea. It was free. Piece of cake was less than a euro. Good cake, really nice Tea. Would definitely recommend the free tour if you’re in the area. The cup of tea afterwards is a lovely treat and we also enjoyed some cake from the cafe! Lovely shop too. It was fascinating seeing the tea making process from plucking to pot. I must admit sadness learning pluckers are $AUD5 daily and white tea sells for $AUD125 for 50 grams. It was great to see the inside of a tea factory and learn about the process of tea making. Unfortunately we arrived on. asunder so much of the factory was not in action. I would have liked to have learnt some more about the history of tea in Sri Lanka though. A nice experience having tea and cake at the end of the tour. Super exciting tour. Short and simple, gave really nice insight into tea production.Good tea and cake. Very friendly people. This is a lovely set up. Earlier this was the Mackwoods Tea Factory, but now it seems that the owners have changed and the entire place has seen an upgrade. Once you arrive, you have the option of going in for a free tour of the factory (15 minutes approx) where you will learn how tea is made. The guide patiently briefs you about the most important details of the tea making business and in the end show the different varieties of tea as well. You can taste the tea as well. Once the tour is over, you are welcomed into the tea lounge, where you can drink unlimited cups of tea as you want. Whilst the tea and sugar are provided, there is a minimal charge if you want milk. They also sell chocolate and tea cakes, both simply done and lovely. The views are SPECTACULAR, no other word can describe it. They have a nice viewing platform that doubles up for outdoor seating (if the weather permits and its not raining) and the experience is very nice and pleasant. Overall, very enjoyable and relaxing, and a special mention to the friendly, respectful staff that are hired there. We had a nice little tour around the factory. The girl who showed us round was brilliant. Great to see how tea is produced. You can go on a jeep tour and tea plucking experience for a hefty sum of money. We would have had to wait 2 and a half hours before the next tour and the price was so high we didn’t do it. Once you have been in the factory, they bring you back in to the main area where they show you the colour difference in the teas. You then get shown the tea buying area where they chase you around trying to sell you tea products. They do give you a free cup of tea and we had some cake which was really nice. Travel with Dimma to Damro Tea in Labukele while driving NuwaraEliya  and  feel the Srilankan uniq Vibrance and feel like Wow.Visit Srillanka.This is best time When they heard that we were Italian they entrusted us to a guide who spoke Italian and learned it simply by listening to tourists. Very good at explaining the whole process that revolves around tea. At the end of the tour they offered us a tasting of really good Black tea. You can purchase sweets to accompany. At the end there is also a shop where you can buy different types of tea. If you're on the road I recommend a stop in this Factory. The experience takes a maximum of 40 minutes, excluding all the time you want to stay and taste tea in the dedicated room. We visited Damro Teas as part of our tour with Dinesh from the wonderful D S Tours (see seperate  review).  We had a guided tour of the factory from Siroma which was very informative.  Afterwards we opted for a vehicle tour of the tea plantation (extra cost).  We are so glad we did, we had numerous photo opportunities with the driver taking many photos of us😀.  We also got you meet some of the lady tea pickers who were lovely.  Thank you to all staff involved in our factory tour and plantation tour. We enjoyed this tour of the tea plantation and tour of the processing area. Tour guides are well informed and can answer any questions you may have. From seeing the ladies picking the tea, the drying and sorting process to the actual cup arriving at your table is an experience  worth taking. The "tea cake" was delicious too. Lovely views over the plantation. Their is a shop where the various teas can be purchased at reasonable prices. Today we went to Damro with an organized tour and the experience was quite bad. Explanations of simple and quick guides and worst store prices. Totally abusive. A trap for full-blown tourists. I recommend not buying anything there. In the normal shops of the village, you can find teas of other brands for a third of the price and with a quality equal to the Dumro. We were not even given a guided tour of the plantation. A real disaster visiting. Having visited this establishment on a Sunday... ( CLOSED...), which the guide we used didn't know.. ABSOLUTE waste of time.. A company guide literally rushed a group of us through the factory.. It was empty of employees, and so we saw nothing of how the process works... It took no more than 10mins to go through to the area where we Began the tour.. Then we were shown the the area where all different teas were available for sale.. So for me it's purely a 'sales push..' Total waste of time in my opinion There is a large decking viewing area at this establishment.. Where you can look at the rows of tea bushes.. Under this decking you will find the very very poor locals, who have no income or jobs.. Begging for you to throw a few notes over the handrail of the decking.. The tea pluckers earn around 2,000 rupees per day.( aprox £5.) They have to pluck 20kgs per day for that pay.. So sad .. Would never return.. You only find out information once you actually leave and the guide explains more... Damro Tea plantation has a big tea estate that caters to local and export needs.  We had a brief 20 minutes tour of the factory.  Picking of the tea leaves is once a week. The picked leaves are placed in huge belts to dry where huge air blowers blow air to aid in the drying process.  This takes about 14 hours of drying. It takes 5 kg fresh leaves to make 1 kg of black tea. Once the leaves are dried they are sent down to the machine where it's rolled and cut as per the requirements.  Then they are placed on the table for fermentation where the process of oxidation changes the colour of the tea leaves. No fermentation for green and white tear.  Then the leaves are sent to the Dryer machine to stop fermentation to turn to black colour.  After this they are sent to the Grading machine for different quality of grading - strong, medium, light.  The tour ends with complimentary light black tea. He reported complaints from multiple customers of his. He also said that foreigners get free entry because they’re likely to buy stuff at the shop. Now there are the same families third fourth generation labour still working there. They have been exploited quite badly. The tea processed is auctioned by the government and then bought by big manufacturers who blend the tea to make it cheaper. As a traveler with a penchant for wildlife, this was a must-visit on my Sri Lankan itinerary. Stepping through the gates, the cacophony of animal calls replaced the city's honking symphony. My first stop was the elephant enclosure. These gentle giants, Sri Lanka's national treasure, were munching on hay. A sense of awe washed over me as I observed their wrinkled grey skin and intelligent eyes.  A young elephant playfully sprayed itself with water from its trunk, a gesture that made me chuckle. Next, the playful chatter of monkeys drew me in. The Sri Lanka Langurs, with their distinctive black faces, swung from branch to branch, seemingly unfazed by the watching crowd.  A troop of macaques squabbled over a fallen banana, their antics providing a moment of amusement. The roar of a lion echoed through the zoo, sending shivers down my spine.  Approaching the lion enclosure with a mix of anticipation and trepidation, I saw the majestic creature lounging in the shade. Its golden mane shimmered in the sunlight, and its powerful presence commanded respect. The Dehiwela Zoo isn't just about the big cats. I wandered past enclosures housing a variety of fascinating creatures, each with its own unique story.  The graceful peacocks strutted their vibrant feathers, the zebras grazed peacefully, and the giraffes stretched their long necks, offering a glimpse into their leafy breakfast. One of the highlights was the feeding time at the hippopotamus enclosure. These enormous creatures lumbered out of the water, eagerly awaiting their meal. This was one of the most horrendous animal experiences I’ve ever encountered. We went with family, who had in turn gone as children to this zoo - so it was a trip down memory lane for them. I was hoping there would be some element of care for the animals - after all, they advertise that you can see elephants, lions, bears, giraffes and more. I was incredibly shocked by what we saw. On arrival we learnt about the “World Children’s Day” event where staff proudly told us school kids are allowed to pet the lion cubs. I was shocked that anyone is allowed to handle the cubs - and can only image what is done to control the cubs in these circumstances (drugging, starvation, lack of water - all to control behaviour). Elephants are chained and poked into submission using ‘phaajaan’ and then made to parade, perform and “dance” - a tradition at this zoo dating back decades apparently. It’s disgusting to watch - much like the old circus activities that are Elephants balance on each other and form shapes. I was shocked at how many local people come here to cheer and champion this treatment, without any care for the treatment of the animals. I would have thought people are more educated about this in 2024 and should know how cruel this is! The worst thing was that there is no acknowledgement of how wrong it is to treat any animals this way. They are blatantly tortured and exploited for human entertainment - and tamed into submission in ways we all know are cruel. Yet people pay to see this. While this might be down to a lack of local education, I suspect that’s not the case in this day and age - rather that, at Dehiwala Zoo, making money is far more important than animal welfare. This zoo should be shut down, and I hope other travellers can help share this message so people do not spend their money here in future. Diyaluma Falls. Diyaluma Falls was one of the best trips we did in Sri Lanka. We rode to the bottom of the falls from Ella ( about 1 hour on a motorbike) wondering if we would have to carry our jackets and helmets on the hike and where to safely park the bike.  We were lucky to be greeted by Saman who took care of everything. His guided hike to the waterfalls was great. He has so much knowledge of the forest, stopping along the way to show us different trees and plants. We spent several hours working our way down the different levels of the waterfall, swimming,  rock jumping and rock sliding. The views were breathtaking and we rated it as one of the best days out on our holiday. Saman’s number is +94787784560 Diyaluma Falls, Sri Lanka’s second-highest waterfall, is a breathtaking natural wonder near Ella. Cascading dramatically from lush green cliffs, it offers stunning views and refreshing natural pools at the top. A short hike rewards visitors with panoramic landscapes and peaceful surroundings. Ideal for nature lovers and adventure seekers, Diyaluma Falls is a perfect spot to swim, relax, and experience Sri Lanka’s raw beauty. The waterfalls are beautiful and the hike is very doable. You can drive (or be driven) quite high up toward the parking area, and from there it’s another 20–30 minutes uphill to reach the top of the falls. However, compared to the many other activities we’ve done in Sri Lanka so far, we found it quite busy at the waterfalls. Our tuk-tuk driver immediately became our guide, but in hindsight we regretted that a little. We were advised to take a guide so you know where to go after reaching the top, but in our experience you can easily figure this out yourself using Google Maps and by following other people. Our guide also seemed quite rushed, while you really want to spend a few hours relaxing in the natural infinity pools. Our advice: definitely go, but don’t take a guide, and make sure to give yourself enough time. Diyaluma Falls was one of the best things we did in Sri Lanka.  Well worth the drive off the main road.  Very manageable hike to get to the top of the falls and I highly recommend going early to beat the crowds.  We were there at 9am and it was perfect.  We also had the good fortune to have Saman as our guide.  His family lives at the base of the falls and he is the expert on safety and all the surrounding flora.  He made our day at the falls unforgettable!  Great communication and was waiting for us when we arrived.  His number is +94787784560 We had an incredible day at the falls with our 6 year old son. Our guide, Saman, was wonderful and definitely meant we got the most out of our trip. We found Saman’s number on other reviews here and text him when we were still in Udawalawe. He agreed to pick us up from our bus in Wellawaya, drive us all the way to the falls, guide us around and then drop us in Ella when we had finished. He offered a really good price for the day. Saman was so friendly and spoke good English. He arrived early to meet us and took us to his family kiosk at the base of the falls where we were able to leave our heavy bags and change our clothes. He gave our son a coconut and then we took the Tuk-tuk further up the hill. From there it was about a 20-30min walk to the falls. On the way Saman taught us all about the plants growing by the side of the trail. He picked lemongrass and cinnamon for us so we could smell them, showed us cashew trees and rubber that had solidified from rubber trees. Our son was fascinated by all his knowledge. Saman then led us to the highest pool where we were able to swim and skim stones. He showed us safe places to slide through the rocks into the water. There are tiny fish in the water that tickle as they nibble your feet. Further down the falls we were able to jump off a 10m ledge into a deep pool below. It was terrifying but absolutely worth it if you can summon the courage. It’s also a great spectator sport if you’re not up for it yourself! Even further down Saman went and found leaves like mini helicopters which he showed our son how to throw into the wind. The view from the top of the waterfall is breath-taking. We had our favourite day so far in Sri Lanka and this was all down to Saman and his brilliant knowledge. He was so kind with our little boy and made him feel really special and cared for. We had wondered if we needed a guide and it’s definitely possible to do it without one but we wouldn’t have had such an amazing experience if it weren’t for Saman. There are places to buy fruit and little restaurants all the way up and down for food. We spent about 3 hours there and the time flew by. 10/10 for this experience. On the way to Ella, Saman stopped and bought us hot corn on the cob from the roadside. It was delicious. Thank you Saman. However more recently during the Sri Lankan Civil War (between 1983 - 2009) a memorial to Corporal Gamini Kularatne who advanced the end of the Civil War, by sacrificing his life and single handedly stopping the advance of a reinforced bulldozer tank armed by the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam -  Tamil Tigers, which were advancing towards a small group / platoon of the Sri Lankan Army. Suddenly Lance Corporal Kularatne, holding two grenades in his hands, dashed out towards the oncoming bulldozer tank, clambered up the tank's ladder and tossed the two grenades inside it, disregarding the numerous injuries he himself had suffered by then from the bullets of LTTE. Within seconds, fiery bursts of fire accompanied by a series of explosions occurred. Lance Corporal Gamini Kularatne was flung to the ground and lay motionless.  Sadly he died in this act of Heroism. In recognition of his act of gallantry Lance Corporal Gamini Kularatne was promoted to the rank of Corporal posthumously and honored with the award of "Parama Weera Vibhushanaya" on 10 October 1991, the highest gallantry award in Sri Lanka for the first time in the history of Sri Lanka Army. Five in the morning is never an enthusiastic time to get up wherever you are in the world and in Sri Lanka it is still dark. Muddle headed, as I had slept in so many different beds this trip, I could not sort out where I was as the light round the door and the chinks in the window were in strange places but there was no mistaking the urgent bleeping of the alarm. Time to begin the day. No breakfast or even a cup of tea, we scrambled to leave Bibile and were on the road and dodging the jogging platoons of soldiers flanked by white clad PT instructors, armed guards, an ambulance and support trucks by 5.30am. Even at that time it was very hot and I did not envy the soldiers in full combat gear and huge rucksacks with guns slung across their chests. Dawn keen reptiles dotted the road, sleepy dogs who had hogged the central position all night on the hot tarmac and startled birds put up by the sound of our engine, were all a backdrop to our journey to Gal Oya and the Boat Safari. Gal Oya National Park lies in the southeast of Sri Lanka and to the west of Ampara. It was established in 1954 by the Gal Oya Development Board mainly to protect the catchment area of the 'Senanayake Samudra' Reservoir and then handed over to the department of Wildlife Conservation in 1965. It is rich in flora and fauna and about 45% of the park is covered by evergreen forest and a further 33% is taken up by savanna areas. The 25,900 hectare park has about 32 species of mammals including common langur (monkey), endemic toque macaque, leopard, sloth bear, elephant, wild boar, water buffalo and three species of deer. We arrived at the Wild Life Office to pay for our safari by 6.0am to find the place locked up and everyone still asleep so it took a while to get this trip organised but then, armed with a huge piece of paper with many terms and conditions writ small, we motored onto the dam embankment to meet our guides. Dawn had now broken and the light golden and glorious. The men had yet to appear so we chatted with the policeman who we had bought an ice cream the day before in return for the chance to drive across the dam and take photos of the lake. It was a beautiful morning, mellow with golden light, hushed with no wind and mirror perfect. It seemed a shame to disturb the surface with a boat…..  Then guides arrived and while we waited for them to locate the petrol, shove the boat further into the water and check the life jackets we chatted some more to the avuncular officer. Life goes very slowly in this haven of tranquility…. While he stood and basked in the glow of what must be one of the most wondrous places to work in this part of the world, the policeman told us about the elephants we would see, the variety of birds and gave us the back story about the statue behind and above us of a famous previous president of Sri Lanka who coincidentally was the grandfather of a man we were due to meet the following week. Languorous minutes later we clambered aboard and off we went in a surge of foam and waves, to approach the first bird island in a gentle curve which took in the huge expanse of water before us. Approximately 150 of Sri Lanka 's 430 species of birds have been observed seen in this region of many small islands covered with forest and outcrops which are haven to elephants and birds. The ‘Kurulu Dupatha’ or the ’Bird Island ‘ and some of these islands are 'infested' with birds as a great many varieties in their entire splendor swarm these islands. You can step on to this Bird Island and walk through the forest up to the outcrop. From here, you can see many bird’s nests, some with eggs and some even with fledglings who are unable to fly away even when they spot you. Elephants have made these islands their own as they are the best swimmers of all the mammals in the park. As our boat idled quietly towards the shore we hardly dare breathe as we lapped nearer and nearer to a bathing elephant. It lazily splashed water over its shoulder and sighed heavily as it sank into the cool lake, leaving a tide line across its back. Another grazed behind, lumbering ponderously as it flicked grass into a ball and fed in the morning light. Here elephants exists without any intrusions and swim from island to island in search of greener pasture. Whilst not  an ornithologists, I could not help be awed by the displays of abandoned free flying by the hosts of birds as they swooped and wheeled in telepathic unison above us. We breakfasted on cheese crackers, oranges, dry biscuits and sipped what was now hot bottled water on a pristine island in the shade. It might have only been about 10.0am but there it was beating hot. The white rocks reflected heat and the glare made seeing painful without sunglasses but in this spot on the lake, nothing could be more perfect. Conversation, translated both ways by my guide, was about life in the west and contrasts to the east. Misconceptions about the golden life in foreign parts from both our perspectives were corrected and broad daylight camp fire tales were told about our previous travels and adventures in Sri Lanka. The guides lamented the lack of tourists in the area yet appreciated the lack of intrusion - a dilemma many face in these wild parts of Sri Lanka. Once back aboard we struggled with the now intense heat radiating off the water and all went quiet while we motored across the entire width of the lake to creep up on a baby elephant testing its limits on a remote shore. No mother in sight, the baby seemed oblivious to us and played and ambled with joy. On the last lap now, we skirted the final island, awash with birds, splattered with guano, excited screeching and cawing filling the air. We circled quietly, hardly making an noise at all, while we were treated to a close up of these birds in their natural habitat. With a sudden cry, one of the guides stood up in the boat and pointed urgently. A great brown log moved, then shifted so fast it was all over in a few seconds and much before anyone could aim a camera. An crocodile, at least 12 feet long, disappeared into the bushes. We raced off round the island to see if we could find it coming out the other side, but it was too well hidden. So three hours after we set off, subdued and exhilarated with being so close to wild life, we moored at the dam, where another party of Sri Lankans with enough gear for a expedition, were waiting to use the boat so they could go out and camp for a night on one of the islands. But we were sated, filled with the sights and sounds of safari, knowing we had got nearer  to birds and elephants than ever we would by foot or land rover. It was an immense privilege. If you would like to go on this Boat Safari and see Gal Oya, I heartily recommend you contact my guide for the day: sidabode.hibernation@gmail.com

Gartmore Falls. Gartmore Falls is a picturesque waterfall formed by a stream flowing from Maussakelle Reservoir. It cascades down in two main segments, creating a stunning view against the backdrop of lush greenery and misty hills. The falls are part of the Gartmore Estate, a tea plantation area, and are accessible by a short hike through scenic trails. It’s a peaceful and less crowded location, making it ideal for nature lovers and hikers. It was great, we had were able to spend in upper falls, looked incredible view from above , infinity pool can be accessible. Green lush mountains and tea plantation near by. Gartmore Falls, near Adam’s Peak, are among the finest in Sri Lanka.  There are swimming opportunities in the pool at the top of the falls.  The best views of the falls and the reservoir below are from viewpoints in the neighbouring tea estate.  Unfortunately the owners of the tea estate are in the process of erecting a forbidding barbed wire fence to restrict access to this area.  We succeeded in persuading the security staff to allow us to walk to the viewpoints.  But others may not be so lucky. Gartmore Falls, also known as Sri Pada Falls, is a beautiful waterfall located near Maskeliya in the central highlands of Sri Lanka. It is situated within the Gartmore Estate, a tea plantation, and offers stunning views of the surrounding tea fields and the towering Adam's Peak (Sri Pada) in the background. The waterfall is about 25 meters (82 feet) in height and cascades down a rocky slope into a serene pool. It's a less frequently visited destination compared to other popular waterfalls in Sri Lanka, making it an ideal spot for nature lovers and those looking for a peaceful retreat. Visitors often enjoy a short hike through tea plantations to reach the falls, which adds to the charm of the experience. As a tour guide with years of experience leading travelers through Sri Lanka’s diverse landscapes, I can confidently say that Gartmore Falls is one of the country’s most enchanting and often overlooked destinations. Here’s why this hidden gem deserves a spot on your travel itinerary. Gartmore Falls is a tranquil and visually stunning destination that offers a refreshing break from the more frequented tourist spots. Its natural beauty and serene environment make it a must-visit for anyone exploring Sri Lanka’s diverse landscapes. Highly recommended for those looking to connect with nature and experience a slice of Sri Lanka’s untouched beauty. #ExploreSriLanka#ScenicLankaPersonalTourDrivers Very beautiful waterfalls near the Reservoir, best place to swim upper side of the waterfall and scenery walk destination DO NOT MISS THE PLACE

This heritage listed temple is the oldest shrine dedicated to Lord Buddha. Built by the merchant brothers Tapassu and Balluka, It is believed, according to early Buddhist scripture that Tapassu and Balluka met Gotama Buddha seven weeks after his enlightenment, they are said to be the Buddha's first lay disciples. He gave them some of his hair and they had it enshrined at Girihandu, thereby making the temple a sacred place for all. 'Girhandu Seya' which dates back almost 2500 years, is the first ever Buddhist Pagoda built in the country enshrining the relics of Lord Buddha. Even today, the premises and its surroundings emnante a very calm and serene atmosphere which is ideal for meditation. The stupa is built on a small hill which rises a couple of hundred feet from the average ground elevation. Many ancient ruins are scattered around the entrance area including the remains of an ancient stone bridge. There is a large beautiful pond near the  stone stairway where you have to begin the climb to the stupa, filled with water flowers and surrounded by aquatic vegetation and many species of birds. The climb up can be quite tiring. On the way you could see ancient stone inscriptions and also rock caves used by  'Arahath' (enlightened) Buddhist Monks for meditation. Once at the top, the scenary is simply breathtaking! The well preserved ruins of the main stupa along with its surrounding structures invariably brings nostalgia to pilgrims and tourists alike. The fact that the place has a very long history and infact being the very first Buddhist Shrine in Sri Lanka built in an era even prior to the formal introduction of Buddhism to the country by Arhath Mahinda Thero adds a uniqueness and a very nostalgic value to  the place. Devastatingly beautiful landscape panoramas. 'Girihandu' lies to the north of Trincomalee. The early morning journey is half of the joy in getting to 'Girihandu Monastery' and 'Akasa Stupa', also known as the 'Tiriyaya Archeological Zone'. There are some six resident 'Hamuduruvo' (Monks) that live at this remote site. In the Buddhist tradition, the Sangha can only possess what the community provides; and you will see that there is very little (either way) at Girihandu. Please... take a big sack of 'Rice', a big box of 'First Aid' supplies and donation money as 'dana' for the devoted and welcoming keepers, of this inspiring, sacred location. Karmically positive deeds, lead to a greater happiness. The history of the site is fascinating and the 'Akasa Stupa' is a really beautiful ruin. However, remains a very active monastic place of worship and veneration. The hilltop setting provides a stunning outlook in all directions. The stairway climb to the top isn't so arduous. In fact it's a very pretty and idyllic walk. Tiriyaya is a rugged and isolated paradise. It took a couple of hours to arrive by way of three wheeler, hired via the Guest house in Trincomalee. It's a 50km journey (100km in total) from Trincomalee Central Bus station. The journey out; at first light, was transformative. There is quite a bit of information available online regarding the site and its history. If in 'Trinco'... then put it on your list of things to do. An enjoyable 'fringe experience'... literally Takes about 15 minutes climb to get to the top by foot. It's a very serene place with many caves, scriptures, ponds & lakes. The view from the top is great. Excavation is still going on & you are not allowed beyond certain points. If you are interested in Buddhism or history, it's worth a visit. Takes about 45 mins drive from Nilaveli. This believed to be the oldest shrine in Sri Lanka constructed by Tapassu and balluka who were merchants who got the blessings of lord Buddha . This has survived many centuries and in spite of the civil war for last 30 years .This is located approximately 50 km from trinco along trinco pulmudai road . Road is extremely good except for the last 2 km , which is a gravel road but mortorable. A must see if you are interested in Sri Lankan heritage and shrines. The original stupa considered to be the first in Sri Lanka built to house the hair relics of Lord buddha are in ruins but the view from the top is breathtaking particularly at sunset. It is a short climb but the some steps are uneven so you have to be mindful if you are travelling with kids or with elderly. There is a place to buy snacks and drinks at the place where you can park your vehicle. Please be mindful that this is a place of worship and that you would be required to dress appropriately. Considered the first Dageba/ Stupa in Sri Lanka, Girihadu Seya was made by the merchants Thapassue Balluka to enshrine a lock of the Buddha's hair. We drove for about 45min to 1 hour from Trinco to Pulmudai to get here. The area was under LTTLE control for quite a while and new buildings have been demolished by them and monks chased away. The main Dageba remains in ruins. There are about 300 steps to get to the Dageba, and if its not in the scorching heat, would not be unpleasant. The view from the top is great. Arisimale Beach is relatively close by.

Tea plants thrive in a specific combination of ideal climate, diverse geography, rich soil, and consistent rainfall. Sri Lanka’s central highlands offer these perfect conditions: high altitudes provide cool temperatures, high humidity, and plentiful, well-distributed rain to hydrate the vegetation. It is this "Goldilocks zone" that allows the slow growth necessary for complex flavors to develop in high-quality tea leaves. A visit to the Glenloch Tea estate immerses you in this environment, featuring a tour of the lush tea fields, the intricate leaf processing factory, and a tasting session. Isinbassagala. This is an ancient temple located on the side of the A9 road between Anuradhapura and Medawachchiya, but very little remains from original constructions.  Thus, from an archeological perspective, the place would get 3 stars. But considering it as a stop over on the way to Jaffna and the very easy access, being literally on the side of a main road I would give it 3.5 half stars. The main attraction today is the newer stupa built atop a rock outcrop and the 360 degree view it offers. There is a car park on the side of the road and a few smalls kiosks from where you can get tea and cold, fresh local orange juice mixed with a sprinkling of pepper (ideal on a hot day). From there you can climb up to the stupa. For the most part there are no steps but the slope is quite gentle and it's a short, easy climb. But do keep your shoes on until you get to the stupa, as the rock can get quite hot during the day. According to the monk we met at the top, the new stupa has been constructed on the site of an old Stupa destroyed by the Britishes who built a lookout post there. Nothing remains today of the old Buddhist constructions, expect for a Budhha's footprint carved in stone kept near the stupa (and a cobra head carved in stone which we couldn't find). The stories attached to the place comes more from folklore than any archeological or historical evidence and are both based on a translation of the Sinhala name given to the place. One version is that this is a place where "isiwara" or sages lived. Other version is that Arhat Mahinda (son of Indian Emperor Asoka who brought Budhdhism to Sri Lanka) arrived here by "iridi" power (I suppose you can say it's something like teleporting) before arriving at Mihintale where he would go on to meet King Devanampiyatissa. [Mihintale is not too far from here and in fact you can clearly see the two white Stupas at Mihintale from atop this rock.] According to this version, it is King Devanampiyatissa who constructed the Stupa here. There is a small building towards the back of the stupa. From there, there is a set of newly constructed steps that lead down to the temple premises. As we had done zero research before visiting we climbed back down the way we came. And then we asked around how to get to the temple....! So, based on the directions we got from the kiosks, we took the vehicle down the right turn you get just before the A9 Road entrance to Isinbessagala (this is coming from Anuradhapura side). It's a dirt road but was in very good condition and you have to drive only about 500 meters to get the temple. On the way there, you would another small Stupa on the side of the road, obviously of ancient origin recently conserved. Then you get to a quite well to do temple, with a several new constructions, right next to an ancient tank (wewa). The image house built in the 1930s - 1940s had some interesting statues and paintings. If you climb up to the rock from the temple you also come across quite a sizable banyan tree and an ancient cave dwelling (which is still in use), but we didn't have time to explore these as we were in a hurry to get back on the road. Must also mention that, when we got down from the vehicle wearing only socks, the monks told us to keep wearing shoes (probably because of the heat) which I thought was very considerate of them. According to the chronicles, in the 5th year after enlightenment, Lord Buddha visited Nagadipa to settle a dispute between two Nàga Kings - Chulodara and Mahodara regarding a gem studded throne. The Buddha preached the virtues of non-violence to the warring factions. He urged them to forget hating each other and be united. The two kings surrounded by their followers listened patiently to the Buddha and decided to end their enmity. After the two warring kings made peace the throne was offered to the Buddha, who returned it to the Naga kings. It was later enshrined in the Nagadipa Stupa and soon became a place of Buddhist veneration. Nagadipa later came to be referred to as Nainativu island with the settlement of Tamils in the island. Kabaragala Mountain. A fascinating place that's within a day's effort. The scenary from atop on a clear day is the reason for it being high on the list of dedicated hikers. An easy climb once you're through the tea Estate and the panorama would compel an hour's stay. Be watchful walking the path along the ridge as some parts are very much on the edge of the steep precipice. Leech activity is to be expected. Be careful climbing up/down the thickly covered savannah in the incline as you would not see where you are about to put your feet. Take time climbing due to this issue. Please bring back all that you take and help bring back what's left by the irresponsible and ignorant. Get the bus to Dolosbage from Gampola and ask the conductor to drop you by the aptly named Craighead Estate, giving indications of the intrepid pioneers from Scotland who opened up much of our tea country.Find your way through the excellently well maintained tea estate and the through the village.And no you do not need a guide. Few folks who you might along the way is all you need to find the foothill of the steep incline through the savanah all the way up until l the view point .Time to the top is under 2 hours even by a senior citizen. Yes the trek is ok for a senior.Watch out for few leeches during the wet season though. View from the top is GOOD in the highest sense. Take extra care if you feel like walking up to the highest point since some parts of the path is bit too close to the precipice. And the view from the very top is second  to what you get to see at the first view point so you might as well decide to not try the summit.. BRING EVERYTHING BACK.INCLUDING THE WHAT'S LEFT BY THE IDIOTS .PLEASE. Kabaragala, at 1506 metres is a nice and easy climb which could be covered within one day with hours to spare. The hike takes one along various types of terrain,right through a mountain village and finally up a savanna type grassy slope to the first view point for breath taking views of the valley below. A journey along the ridge from the first view point would take the traveler to the summit. Public Transport to the foothills is available from both Gampola and Nawalapitiya. The first view point of the mountain could be reached within just 2 hours after starting the climb. Path is clear till the edge of the village and from then onward its savanna with the trees at the top of the hill  clearly visible .Road to Craighead, at the start of the trail is in good condition .Expect a degree of leech activity during the rainy season.
